Description: Lower body fragment of an East Greek black-figured pottery large open vessel, probably a krater. Two zones preserved separated by a single line: (a) hoofed animal to right (the hoof preserved) and a petal-incised rosette; (b) grazing geese to left; below the lower frieze, three lines. The glaze of the interior of the vessel fired to reddish brown (2.5 YR 4.5/4).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Boardman in his review of Venit suggests this is rather Attic
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 17, no. 54 pl. 13)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.489)
